awd_titl_txt: Material Transformation and Community Creation at the Etowah Site, Georgia
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Adam King and colleagues seek to explore changes in the built environment of the Etowah site and how those changes reflect community organization and the community formation process itself. While this study is firmly grounded in material culture, architecture, and the use of space the intent is to use data generated through remote sensing as a primary source for interpretation. Traditionally, the data generated through techniques such as gradiometry, ground-penetrating radar, and electrical resistance have only been used as guides for where to excavate to evaluate ideas and learn about the past. In part the emphasis on remote sensing is a conscious effort to reduce the impacts (of excavation) on the archaeological record of Etowah -- a precious resource to some and sacred to others. Additionally, the emphasis on remote sensing data is intended to push the interpretive limits of those data.

This project to explore the creation of the social groups living at Etowah through the built environment will contribute to continuing efforts to understand the formation of complex, often multi-ethnic communities of the Mississippian period. Because the establishment and creation of the physical space of a community is a human universal, what is learned from these efforts will contribute to broader attempts, spanning time and geography, to explore the creation of society using space and architecture. Methodologically, this project attempts to push the limits of non-invasive investigations by asking questions of geophysical data that traditionally have been asked only of excavated data. The results may make it possible to study the development of prehistoric communities like Etowah using only geophysical data and information from very limited and targeted excavations.


Today the Etowah site is a state park and a prehistoric archaeological site famous for having some of the largest earthen platform mounds built in the Deep South, and producing some of the most impressive art objects ever found in the Southeast. In the past it was a thriving Native American community and capital of a larger polity: a role it played for some 550 years during the Mississippian period of the Native American past. Etowah's archaeological record not only captures the structure of those communities, but it also contains traces of the process through which those Etowah communities were formed. Communities are collections of people who, through various means, forge themselves into a social unit with a shared sense of identity, history, and community practice. Community creation is a complex and ongoing process that is part of the universal human experience, and it is encoded into the use of space, architecture, and material culture. This project uses remote sensing data and limited archaeological excavation to explore how Etowah's built environment and associated material culture were transformed with each new incarnation of the Etowah community and in turn examine the process of community creation.

This project to explore the creation of the social groups living at Etowah through the built environment will contribute to continuing efforts to understand the formation of complex, often multi-ethnic communities of the Mississippian period. Because the establishment and creation of the physical space of a community is a human universal, what is learned from these efforts will contribute to broader attempts, spanning time and geography, to explore the creation of society using space and architecture. Methodologically, this project attempts to push the limits of non-invasive investigations by asking questions of geophysical data that traditionally have been asked only of excavated data. The results may make it possible to study the development of prehistoric communities like Etowah using only geophysical data and information from very limited and targeted excavations.

This project will also serve an important teaching function. The archaeological data will be collected by field school students as they learn the process of archaeology, and the geophysical and archaeological data produced will form the basis for a graduate student theses. It is also designed to involve descendant communities in the exploration and interpretation of their history. Members of culturally affiliated Creek and Cherokee communities will be invited to participate in the data collection, the interpretation of the results and in learning from those interpretations.

por.por_cntn:
The funds for this project were used explore the nature of the communities associated with the Native American town known today as the Etowah Indian Mounds Historic Site (9Br1), located in northwestern Georgia. Between AD 1000 and 1550, Etowah was occupied and abandoned three times, so it provides a unique opportunity to study the creation of communities during the Mississippian period. This is a time period when some Native American places and their inhabitants rose above others and became capitals of sometimes large polities called chiefdoms.

To explore Etowah’s communities, close-interval remote sensing surveys and limited archaeological testing were conducted at Etowah. The most important result of this work has been the clear connection of two different magnetic signatures, identified using a fluxgate gradiometer, to two different styles of buildings (wall-trench and single-set post) that date to two different time periods. This is important because now it is no longer necessary to excavate large areas to see the how the communities at Etowah were arranged. Compared to traditional excavation methods, remote sensing data is inexpensive to collect, can be collected quickly over large areas, and is does not impact buried archaeological resources.

These results have revealed new patterns in the history of Etowah. They suggest that the earliest communities at the site (AD 1000-1100) were much larger than originally thought and contained a series of smaller neighborhoods or sub-communities. This fits nicely with the argument that these first communities brought together distinct social groups into a new kind of social order. After being abandoned and re-established (AD 1250-1375), Etowah became a large and formalized center with large earthen mounds, plazas and a fortification wall and ditch. At this time, there are fewer buildings visible inside the site and, based on our limited data from outside of Etowah, became more common outside of the palisade wall. After yet another period of abandonment, caused by the burning of Etowah, people returned to create a more modest town (AD 1475-1550).

Through this work some unique architecture at Etowah was explored at Etowah, including a large circular building and a low platform. The circular buildings are rare at Etowah and, based on other examples found at Etowah and another site, seem to be associated with platform mounds and special contexts that involved important people and ritual. The low platform is unusual became it is built like other platform mounds, but is quite low (about 1 m tall) and rectangular instead of square.

Beyond improving our ways of understanding the past and revealing more details about Etowah’s history, this project contributed to larger goals. One of those was the training of students in archaeological research. The excavations were conducted by a field school attended by students from the University of South Carolina and Texas State University. The students learned how to design archaeological research, conduct field investigations, and also the basics of artifact processing and classification. After the field school, another 200 students in classes at the University of South Carolina also learned artifact processing and classification as part of the Principle Investigator’s anthropology classes.

This project reached beyond the traditional classroom and involved descendant communities, as well. During the field school, some 20 volunteers from the local community, including members of Boy Scouts of America, assisted in the excavations and artifact processing. Many of them learned the fundamental of archaeological field work along with the students.
